Award.AbstractNarration:
The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN in Geneva Switzerland is the world's premier particle collider facility in operation. By recording the collisions of protons at the LHC, the ATLAS experiment studies nature at the shortest distances and highest masses ever accessible in a laboratory. In essence, it is simultaneously the world's most powerful microscope and an experiment creating conditions that existed in nature only near the time of the Big Bang. Studies there have already led to discovery of a new fundamental particle, the Higgs Boson. This discovery is of such high scientific impact that the 2014 Nobel Prize in Physics was given to the people who first predicted the existence of this particle.

This NSF award enables upgrades of the ATLAS experimental apparatus needed for high precision studies of Higgs Boson properties and a wide variety of searches for particles needed to explain unresolved puzzles. An example of one such puzzle is "What is the dark matter which makes up nearly 30% of the universe"? There are many other similar questions. The next three years represent a transition of the LHC physics program from a collision energy of 8 Teraelectronvolts (TeV) data-taking and operation, to extended operations and data taking at nearly double the energy, 13-14 TeV. Over a thousand scientists from the United States are involved with this scientific program on several major experiments.

This award provides support for Dr. Hobbs at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and his collaborators at three U.S. universities to upgrade the ATLAS detector so that it can continue to operate efficiently at higher energies for a longer time and at a higher rate. This upgrade will enable scientists to collect data to search for new physics to explain inconsistencies in the particle theory that arise as the energy is increased and to fully understand how the Higgs boson fits into a fundamental theory of the universe.

The universities supported by this award will build new instrumentation to be installed in the ATLAS detector, which is necessary in order to carry out a real-time selection and collection of data and provide a better measurement of particle energies. In addition to producing results which advance fundamental scientific knowledge, the work associated with these upgrades trains students, young researchers and technicians to carry out basic research by formulating questions and procedures to understand what is not known, and it also trains them to develop and operate complex, custom electronics systems and advanced computer algorithms needed to sustain extremely high data rates and classify large, complex data sets in fractions of a second.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded upgrades to the trigger system of the ATLAS experimental apparatus at CERN. The ATLAS experiment records data from proton-proton collisions in the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) which are used to study the structure of nature at the smallest scales and highest energies ever created in a laboratory. Corresponding conditions existed in nature only near the time of the Big Bang. The most significant early outcome from this research was the discovery of the Higgs Boson. This resulted in the ATLAS collaboration being awarded the Fundamental Physics Prize, and a Nobel Prize for the theorists who predicted the Higgs Bosons decades ago. The research program is continuing with measurements of the Higgs Boson properties and ongoing searches for evidence of new physics which is not included in our current best theory. If found, this new physics could explain outstanding mysteries of the universe.

The ATLAS trigger system filters collision data reducing the raw rate of 40 million collisions per second to a rate of approximately 1000 per second which then are kept for analysis. It is this saved data which becomes the input to all ATLAS research results. The accuracy of the trigger filters is therefore a crucial element of ATLAS. Collision data which is not selected by the trigger system is lost forever.

As the LHC proton beam intensity surpassed the design specification, it became clear that to retain the accuracy of the trigger system, upgraded components were needed. This award funded the design and construction of key pieces of these upgrades including custom integrated circuit chips and digital electronics to read out the data used to make trigger decisions. The work was a collaboration among Stony Brook University, Columbia University, Michigan State University and Southern Methodist University along with other U.S. and international collaborating universities and laboratories. The upgrade electronics production was completed in 2019 and sent to CERN for installation in ATLAS and subsequent use during data taking.
